title: First Baptist Church of Ossining
text:
The First Baptist Church of Ossining is located in the center of the <a href="Administrative%20divisions%20of%20New%20York%23Village">village</a> of <a href="Ossining%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">Ossining</a>, New York, United States. It is a brick building in the <a href="Gothic%20Revival">Gothic Revival</a> <a href="architectural%20style">architectural style</a> with a tall wooden steeple built in the 1870s, one of Ossining's most prominent landmarks. In 1973 it was listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>. Sixteen years later, in 1989, it was included as a <a href="contributing%20property">contributing property</a> to the <a href="Downtown%20Ossining%20Historic%20District">Downtown Ossining</a> <a href="historic%20district%20%28United%20States%29">Historic District</a> when it was listed on the Register.
First Baptist, begun in late 18th-century <a href="prayer%20meeting">prayer meeting</a>s, is the oldest religious congregation in Ossining. Founder Elijah Hunter, who also established Ossining, began holding regular prayer meetings at his house in 1786. In the church's early years, masters and <a href="Slavery%20in%20New%20York">slaves</a> held equal standing as congregants. The church was later instrumental in helping establish <a href="black%20church">black church</a>es in the area.
Building.
The church <a href="land%20lot">lot</a> takes up most of the triangular block at the crossroads where Ossining was first established, between Main Street on the northwest, Church Street on the southwest, and South Highland Avenue (<a href="U.S.%20Route%209%20in%20New%20York">U.S. Route 9</a>) on the east. Ellis Place is directly opposite the church. The block is just south of the intersection with Croton Avenue (<a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%20133">New York State Route 133</a>).
On the northern tip of the triangle is a former bank building. The opposite side of Main Street is lined with a row of two-story 19th-century brick commercial buildings. Just west of the church, as the terrain slopes gently toward the <a href="Hudson%20River">Hudson River</a>, the trail following the <a href="Old%20Croton%20Aqueduct">Old Croton Aqueduct</a>, a <a href="National%20Historic%20Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a>, crosses Main. Across Church is a large parking lot between two larger commercial buildings. <a href="Ossining%20High%20School">Ossining High School</a> is a short distance to the southeast on the east side of South Highland. Immediately opposite the church are houses south of Ellis and another house of worship, Trinity Episcopal Church, on the north corner.
Exterior.
A low cast-iron fence surrounds the lot, shaded on the east side by tall mature trees. The building itself is a one-and-a-half–story T-shaped brick structure on a stone foundation. Its steeply pitched <a href="gabled">gabled</a> roofs are shingled in <a href="slate">slate</a> and pierced by four similarly gabled <a href="dormer%20window">dormer window</a>s on either side. On the east corner of the south (front) elevation is a tall <a href="steeple%20%28architecture%29">steeple</a> with the main entrance. The west elevation has a shed-roofed wing.
That facade has a large five-part <a href="lancet%20arch">lancet arch</a>ed <a href="stained%20glass%20window">stained glass window</a> springing from a stone belt <a href="course%20%28architecture%29">course</a>. In its upper woodwork are <a href="quatrefoil">quatrefoil</a>s, the church exterior's principal <a href="motif%20%28visual%20arts%29">motif</a>, surmounted by segmented <a href="limestone">limestone</a>. Two <a href="fluting%20%28architecture%29">fluted</a> wooden colonettes rising from <a href="corbel">corbel</a>s on either side support an intricate <a href="vergeboard">vergeboard</a> with more quatrefoils amid it. It hides the exposed <a href="Hammerbeam%20roof">hammerbeam</a> <a href="truss">truss</a>es of the roof's structural system.
A smaller two-part window at the front of the west wing has a similar treatment to the main window, with a smaller quatrefoil. Just around the corner is a gabled side entrance with projecting roof supported by side <a href="bracket%20%28architecture%29">brackets</a> and a large quatrefoil in the <a href="transom%20%28architecture%29">transom</a>. The four small tripartite arched stained glass windows along the facade to the north are separated by <a href="buttress">buttress</a>es. At their north another steep gabled projection with quatrefoil and vergeboards shelters a taller, narrow tripartite arched window. At the very end is a smaller, narrower window with corresponding quatrefoil. On the east, a fifth window is located at the south end; otherwise, its <a href="Window">fenestration</a> is identical. The roof dormers, on both sides, have vergeboards that form quatrefoils.
Both ends of the rear section are centered around large blind lancet arches with crosses. Below the west window are three narrow windows set in the same wood as the arch; the east side has two arched double-hung windows beneath the blind arch with a third such window to the north and a single-paned diamond-glass window to the south. A vergeboard pattern echoes the arch on the west end; the east end has no vergeboards but a row of corbeled bricks paralleling the roofline.
On the north facade the central section projects slightly. It has a window similar to its counterpart upfront, without the flanking colonettes. Above it are the exposed trusses, without any vergeboards. The two sections on the rear of the cross-section have narrow windows in their exposed basement and a single tripartite lancet-arched stained-glass window in the second story.
Steeple.
The first of the steeple's four stages has corner buttresses and two stone belt courses, the upper one serving as the springline for the quatrefoiled transom over the main entrance on the south side. Another course, slightly flared, marks the beginning of the next stage, with a narrow lancet window in the center of each side. Each has diamond glass and some vergeboard in the arch.
Above each window is the beginning of a square wooden central column that divides the two <a href="louver">louver</a>ed lancet-arched vents on each face, now done in painted <a href="galvanized">galvanized</a> sheet iron rather than brick. Midway up each corner, smaller square columns begin. All rise through the <a href="cornice">cornice</a> that tops the third stage, where they end in pyramids topped by nested pyramids, the corners higher than the central columns, all echoing the steeple's peaked roof. At its top is a small <a href="Celtic%20cross">Celtic cross</a>.
Interior.
A heavy wooden double door in a limestone-topped lancet arch leads into the <a href="sanctuary">sanctuary</a>. It leads to an interior with extensive and ornate <a href="woodcarving">carved woodwork</a> in Gothic motifs set amid plaster walls. A wide central aisle divides the box <a href="pew">pew</a>s, their aisle ends topped with a trefoil motif. Two narrower aisles run through the side sections from either entrance. The floor is carpeted. The intricate stained-glass windows depict Biblical scenes of importance to the church's evangelical beliefs.
Round wooden columns, corniced midway up, support the ceiling's exposed trusses. Narrower columns support the balcony in the rear, and the three-faceted balcony with the church's <a href="pipe%20organ">pipe organ</a> over the altar, raised five feet () off the floor. Atop it is an white marble <a href="baptistry">baptistry</a>. The rooms in the basement are used for <a href="Sunday%20school">Sunday school</a> classes, meetings and office space.
History.
Elijah Hunter, a captain in the <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">Revolutionary War</a> who founded Ossining, started holding Baptist prayer meetings at his house in 1786. This grew rapidly, and four years later, 33 congregants formally incorporated the church. They continued to meet in homes until Hunter donated the land for a small meeting house on the present site in 1815. During the early years, <a href="History%20of%20slavery%20in%20New%20York">slaves</a> and their masters attended services. Both were considered full members of the congregation, and treated equally in the church.
The original building was altered in 1834, and again in 1850. Originally the church had no facility for <a href="baptism">baptism</a>s, so those took place in a small cove on the <a href="Hudson%20River">Hudson River</a> just south of where <a href="Ossining%20%28Metro-North%20station%29">the village's train station</a> is now. In 1865 the present white marble <a href="baptistry">baptistry</a> was installed.
By that time the church was beginning to outgrow its original structure, and the congregation began considering a new one. Brooklyn architect J. Walsh's <a href="Gothic%20Revival">Gothic Revival</a> design, with triangles and <a href="quatrefoil">quatrefoil</a>s representing the <a href="Trinity">Trinity</a> and the four <a href="Gospel">Gospel</a>s respectively, was dedicated in 1874. It had cost $75,000 ($ in modern dollars) for local contractor John Hoff to build. The church was able to finance it purely from donations from the congregation, without taking out a mortgage.
Later in the 19th century the church continued its early tradition of support for the local African-American community. At its centennial celebrations in 1890, an itinerant African-American minister requested the church's help in establishing a '<a href="black%20church">black</a>' Baptist Church in the village. First Baptist and its congregation responded, and Star of Bethlehem Baptist Church was established on South Spring Street. It continues to hold services today.
In 1916 the church was wired for electricity. Almost a century later, after its 200th anniversary celebrations, the church and donors were able to restore all the original stained glass windows. There have been no significant alterations to the building other than those.
The church today.
Ossining First Baptist follows a traditional Baptist creed. "The Bible is the inspired and only infallible Word of God and our rule and guide for Faith, Life and Doctrine", its website says. This includes a belief in the <a href="Trinity">Trinity</a>, the <a href="Christology%23Person%20of%20Christ">divinity of Christ</a>, and <a href="salvation">salvation</a> through "<a href="repentance">repentance</a> and faith in the blood of Christ alone".
The church holds adult <a href="Sunday%20school">Sunday school</a> and junior church for children every Sunday, with <a href="Eucharist">Communion</a> held on the first Sunday of every month. Services are televised on cable channels in the Ossining area, with <a href="streaming%20media">streaming video</a> available over the Internet at telemissions.com. During the rest of the week men's and women's fellowship sessions are held along with <a href="Bible%20study%20%28Christian%29">Bible study</a> groups. The church also operates a <a href="thrift%20shop">thrift shop</a>. Two Spanish-language services are held every week to serve the area's growing <a href="Latin%20American%20culture">Latin immigrant</a> population.
